title: CI for Mean with Unknown Variance
contentHtml: In this worked example, we'll derive a T-interval confidence interval (CI) for the mean of a population when the sample variance is unknown.

problem.statementHtml: A random sample of size n=16 is taken from a normal distribution with unknown mean and variance. The sample mean is \bar{x}=25, and the sample standard deviation is s=3.

workedExample.problemHtml: Construct a 95% CI for the population mean using the sample data above.

steps.description: Calculate the sample mean and standard deviation
steps.explanation: We need these values to construct the T-statistic.
The T-statistic is used to determine the critical value from the T-distribution.
The degrees of freedom are used to find the critical value from the T-distribution.

steps.description: Find the critical value from the T-distribution
steps.explanation: We use the degrees of freedom and the desired confidence level to find the critical value.
The CI is constructed by adding and subtracting the product of the critical value, the standard deviation, and the square root of the sample size from the sample mean.

intuition: The T-interval CI provides a way to estimate the population mean when the sample variance is unknown.

subject: statistics
title: T-Interval Estimation for Mean (Unknown Variance)
contentHtml: In this worked example, we'll demonstrate how to construct a T-interval estimate for the mean of a population when the sample variance is unknown.

problem.statementHtml: A random sample of size 25 is taken from a normal distribution with unknown mean and variance. The sample mean is 12.5, and the sample standard deviation is 2.1.

workedExample.problemHtml: Construct a 95% confidence interval for the population mean using the sample data provided.

steps.explanation: We need to calculate the standard error of the mean to determine the width of our interval.

steps.description: Determine the critical value from the T-distribution
steps.explanation: We'll use a T-table or calculator to find the critical value corresponding to our desired confidence level and degrees of freedom.
The margin of error is the product of the critical value and the standard error.
Our interval estimate is simply the sample mean plus or minus the margin of error.

intuition: The T-interval provides a way to construct an interval estimate for the population mean when the sample variance is unknown.

title: T-Interval Estimation for Mean (Unknown Variance)
contentHtml: In this worked example, we'll solve a problem step-by-step to demonstrate T-interval estimation for the mean of a population with unknown variance.

problem.statementHtml: A random sample of size 25 is taken from a population with unknown variance. The sample mean is calculated to be 10.2. Construct a 95% T-interval estimate for the true population mean.
hints: Hint: Use the sample standard deviation

workedExample.problemHtml: A random sample of size 25 is taken from a population with unknown variance. The sample mean is calculated to be 10.2.

steps.explanation: We need the sample variance to construct the T-interval.
The standard error is used to determine the critical value for the T-distribution.
We use a t-table or calculator to find the critical value for a two-tailed test with α = 0.05.
The T-interval is constructed by adding and subtracting the product of the critical value and standard error from the sample mean.

intuition: The T-interval provides a range of values within which we can be confident that the true population mean lies.

subject: statistics
title: T-Interval Estimation for Mean (Unknown Variance)
contentHtml: In this example, we'll use the T-interval to estimate the mean of a population given a sample with unknown variance.

workedExample.problemHtml: Suppose we have a random sample of size n = 25 from a normal distribution with unknown mean μ and variance σ2. We want to construct a T-interval estimate for μ.

steps.explanation: We start by calculating the sample mean, which is a natural estimator for the population mean.
Next, we calculate the sample variance using the formula for unbiased estimation.
The T-statistic is a standardized measure of how far our sample mean is from the population mean.
We use the T-distribution to find the critical value corresponding to our desired confidence level.
Finally, we construct the T-interval by adding and subtracting the critical value multiplied by the standard error.

intuition: The T-interval provides a way to estimate the population mean while accounting for uncertainty in both the sample mean and variance.
